review.title: CDF-Intervals: A Reliable Framework to Reason about Data with Uncertainty
review.abstract: This research introduces a new constraint domain for reasoning about data with uncertainty. It extends convex modeling with the notion of p-box to gain additional quantifiable information on the data whereabouts. Unlike existing approaches, the p-box envelops an unknown probability instead of approximating its representation. The p-box bounds are uniform cumulative distribution functions (cdf) in order to employ linear computations in the probabilistic domain. The reasoning by means of p-box cdf-intervals is an interval computation which is exerted on the real domain then it is projected onto the cdf domain. This operation conveys additional knowledge represented by the obtained probabilistic bounds. Empirical evaluation shows that, with minimal overhead, the output solution set realizes a full enclosure of the data along with tighter bounds on its probabilistic distributions.
histories: 10 pages, 15 Postscript figures, uses new_tlp.cls and acmtrans.bst, full version of a paper accepted to be presented at the Doctoral Consortium of the 30th International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP 2014), July 19-22, Vienna, Austria. arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1405.2801

metadata.title: CDF-Intervals: A Reliable Framework to Reason about Data with Uncertainty

sections.text: ar Xiv: 140 5.40 08v1 [cs.LO] KEYWORDS: convex structures, reliable reasoning with limitations, probability field, cdf interval, satisfaction problem with limitations, constraint programming, constraint reasoning, uncertainty

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This research proposes a novel constraint domain for arguing about data with uncertainty, driven by the practical application of reliable approaches in constraint programming (CP), which intuitively and comprehensibly solve problems related to data insecurity, but which lack knowledge when considering the whereabouts of the data. Often, the purpose of this novel framework is to describe data probability or probability of occurrence, which in turn can be poorly defined or vary in nature. It is important to know the source and nature of the data in order to think about it. The purpose of this novel framework is to intuitively describe data that are coupled with uncertainty or follow unknown distributions, without losing any knowledge of the problem definition. cdf intervals extend the cdf interval approach (Saad et al.

sections.heading: 5 Empirical evaluation
sections.text: In fact, one sees oneself in the position of being in the reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary reactionary.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and future research direction
sections.text: The key idea is to extend convex models to include the notion of p-boxes in order to provide additional quantifiable information about the whereabouts of the data. P-boxes have never been implemented in the CP paradigm before, yet they are very good candidates for dealing with and reasoning about uncertainty in the probabilistic paradigm, especially when the data forms an unknown distribution. The case study of the inventory management problem shows that p-box cdf intervals can be applied practically to intuitively comprehend the uncertain data found in various modeling aspects with minimal overhead. Evaluation results show that stochastic CPs and probable models have the slowest performance. Fuzzy models have proven to be more powerful and their output solutions are reliable, i.e. they seek the satisfaction of all possible realizations. Convex models and the p-box cdf intervals have all possible distributions.

referenceMentions.context: The p-box cdf-intervals extend the cdf-intervals approach, (Saad et al. 2010), with a p-box structure to obtain a safe enclosure.
This enclosure envelops the data along with its whereabouts with two distinct quantile values, each is issuing a cdf-uniform distribution, (Saad et al. 2012).
They are adopted in the CP paradigm in fuzzy Constraint Satisfaction Problems (CSPs) (Dubois et al. 1996) and numerical CSPs (Benhamou and de Vinci 1994).
They are the heart of the probabilistic CP modeling found in valued CSP (Schiex et al. 1995), semirings (Bistarelli et al.
1995), semirings (Bistarelli et al. 1999), stochastic CSPs (Walsh 2002), scenario-based CSPs (Tarim et al.
1999), stochastic CSPs (Walsh 2002), scenario-based CSPs (Tarim et al.
It is based on a probability box (p-box) structure (Ferson et al. 2003) that envelops a set of cumulative distribution functions (cdf).
37 in the cdf-intervals representation proposed in (Saad et al. 2010), the fuzzy cdf value Fx = 0.
Together they permit for a new definition of unification which extends the well-known Prolog unification (Le Huitouze 1990; Holzbaur 1992).
This operation is opposed to the fuzzy extended addition operation adopted in the constraint reasoning utilized in the possibilistic domain (Dutta et al. 2005; Petrović et al. 1996),
and to the Normal probabilistic addition which has a high computation complexity that is due to the Normal distribution shape (Glen et al. 2004).
The inventory management problem model proposed by (Tarim and Kingsman 2004) is employed, as a case study, to evaluate the proposed framework.
